note.p: Career: Assistant, Royal College of Chemistry (1850-1854); Superintendent of Meteorology, Radcliffe Observatory, Oxford (1854); founded (1859) and edited 'Chemical News'; had a private laboratory in 7 Kensington Park Gardens; discovered thalium (1861)
Medals/Prizes: Royal Medal 1875; Davy Medal 1888; Copley Medal 1904
Obituaries: Proc Roy Soc Series A 1919-1920 vol 96 pp i-ix, plate, signed by W A T
References: Vanity Fair 21 May 1903 - "Ubi Crookes ibi lux"
Sir George Thomson, 'An Unfortunate Experiment: Hertz and the Nature of Cathode Rays' in NR 1970 vol 25 pp 237-242
A Gibson and W V Farrar, 'Robert Angus Smith, FRS, and "Sanitary Science"' in NR 1973-4 vol 28 pp 241-262
Frank A J L James, 'Of "Medals and Muddles". The Context of the Discovery of Thallium: William Crookes's Early Spectro-Chemical Work' in NR 1984-85 vol 39 pp 65-90
W H Brock 'The Royal society's Glass Workers' Cataract Committee; Sir William Crookes and the development of sunglasses' NR 2007 vol 61 pp301-312
